addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

13 Junij
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L./

page.lettertext:
fol.138r
May it please yo
r
good L. I am newly
come to
Dorkum,
whiche is from
Groeninghen
half a daies jorney: and heere I have mette
w
t
e
Councel of state
. The
Count
is come
w
t
all his forces, and is already encamped, w
t
in a litle English mile of
e towne of Groenighen,
It is thought that by this he hath stopped all the
passages, that they can not be relieved w
t
provi-
sion of victuall. But we can not yet learne
what stoare is in
e towne.
Verdugo
hath di-
versly endevoured to putt in a Garrison, w
ch
they w
t
in w
t
stand very stoutely: and, they say, it
is a cause that they are greatly devided.
Upon
e first arrival of
e Court,
e Enemie was
stricken, w
t
so great a terror, as they abandoned
presently 15 places of strength: of w
ch
e grea-
test part were sconces and fortes,
at might well
have abidden
e shotte of
e Canon. Howbeit
to animat
e towne, and to hinder o
r
approching,
Verdugo is encamped between us and the towne:
but under savegard of
e canon, and, by common
conjecture, w
t
some 1400 men. It is thought
he is in hope to intertene us that way, till the
towne my be succoured w
t
farther forces from
the
Duke.
Who, as we are informed, is comming
thitherward in person, w
t
5000 foote, and 600 horse.
Whe t her it be to come directly thither, or to invade
some other place, while we are busied in these quarters,
we can not yet understand. But
e Count hath
left behinde in
Guelderland
and
Utrecht
15
enseignes of foote, and half a cornet, to impeache
his attemptes. And yet
e Frisons are so farward
in the extraordinary furtherance of this present
enterprise, as they have renforced
e army with
as many newe enseignes: so as yet we doe
fol.138v
recken that they come at
e lest, that are in these
partes, to 12000 horse and foote. Because
I knowe not very well, howe my letters from
hens will be safely conveied, by reason of my
going so farre into
e contrey, and because they
must passe through many mens handes, I doe ther-
fore purpose, accordingly as mater and messengers
are presented, to send yo
r
L. sometimes
e double
copie of a letter.
And so I take my humble
leave. From Dorkum. 13 June 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
Before I had shutte up my letter,
we had freshe intelligence from
Count Maurice, and from sundrie
other places, that
e D. of Parma for
certaine hath passed
e Rhine, and
doth advance his comming w
t
all
possible diligence. Whether we shall
attend, and encounter w
t
him, wherto
as it seemeth, Count Maurice is bent, or
shall take some other course by retraict,
or entrenching, as
e Councel is inclined,
who thinke
e state of
e contrey will
be otherwise hazarded, I can not yet
signifie. But they determine this
morning to goe towardes
e army,
to c
o
ferre w
t
Count Maurice.
This is every mans hope, that
e
army of
e Duke shall be destitute
of meanes, to continewe long in
these quarters, for want of victuall.
